children.name: to do the same as sb else
copy
children.definition: to do the same things that sb else does, especially in order to look like them or be like them: bắt chước
examples: Children learn swearing from copying their parents and siblings.
Martin often claimed he copied Bing Crosby’s singing style, but there was much more to his music than that.
Children often copy what they see on television.
I found myself copying him and his mannerisms.

children.name: imitate
children.definition: to copy the way sb behaves, speaks, writes, or moves, especially because youadmirethem or want to be like them: bắt chước
examples: She was a splendid mimic and loved to imitate Winston Churchill.
‘Don’t you talk to me like that!’ she said imitating her mother’s high-pitched voice.
A lot of writers have tried to imitate Lawrence’s style.
►Do not useimitateto mean ‘do the same thing as someone else’. Usecopy:She worries that Tom will copy his brother (NOT imitate his brother) and leave home.

children.name: do what sb does U
children.definition: do what sb doesinformalto do the same things as sb else, especially in order tolearnfrom them: bắt chước, làm theo
examples: Just watch and do what I do. It’s pretty easy.

children.name: follow sb's example
children.definition: followsb’sexample to copy what sb else has done because you think that theirbehaviouroractionswere a good idea: noi theo, noi gương
examples: Brian persuaded his brothers to follow his example and join the navy.
Following the example of Nixon, a politician he greatly admired, he decided to try to make himself more appealing to voters.

children.name: impersonate
children.definition: to pretend to be sb else by copying the way they talk, walk, dress etc, especially in order to make people think you are really the other person: giả danh, mạo nhận
examples: ▪ Harmon is charged with impersonating a police officer.
▪ She makes a living out of impersonating Tina Turner in shows and films.
impersonation[countable/uncountable noun] impersonate of
do an impersonation
▪ Katy does a great impersonation of Grandpa when he’s annoyed.

children.name: ape
children.definition: to imitate sb’s behaviour, in a way that other people think is stupid or silly: nhại
examples: ▪ His music attempts to ape classical styles, but the results are not very original.
▪ California wine makers are trying to do new things with Sauvignon blanc instead of just aping French styles.

children.name: follow sb’s lead
children.definition: follow suitC2/ C2 to do what sb else has just done because it seems the correct thing to do : làm theo
examples: We’re hoping that Europe will follow the US’s lead and ban all use of these poisonous gases.
Because the Black community has long experience with civil rights issues, other minority groups may follow its lead.
Other oil companies are expected to follow suit and raise prices before the end of the month.

children.name: follow in sb’s footsteps
children.definition: to do sth that sb else has done before you, especially sb in a more powerful position than you: noi gương, làm theo đó

children.name: My father was always disappointed that Joey didn’t follow in his footsteps and take over the farm
examples: We will watch with interest what happens to these two women officers and to the young women who wish to follow in their footsteps.

children.name: to copy sb' voice or behaviour to make people laugh
imitate
children.definition: to copy what sb says or does, in order to make people laugh: bắt chước, nhại
examples: ▪ She’s really good at imitating our teacher’s Scottish acce

children.name: imitation
children.definition: /impression to copy the way sbfamousmoves, talks etc, in order to make people laugh: nhại
examples: He made her laugh hysterically during their walks, with his impression of Gene Kelly doing ‘Singin' in the Rain.’
do an imitation/ impression
She does a really good impression of the president.
She can do a wonderful imitation of a blackbird's song.
in imitation of
Ten-year-olds have started wearing lipstick and make-up in imitation of the older girls.

children.name: mimic
children.definition: to unkindly copy the way sb talks or moves in order to make people laugh: nhại
examples: ‘Hmm,’ Phil said. ‘Hmm,’ Graham mimicked.
Yolanda mimicked their father opening the letter.

children.name: take-off
children.definition: a  of somebody/somethingalsoa take-off on somebody/somethingAmerican informal /ə ˈteɪk ɒf əv somebody/something, ə ˈteɪk ɒf ɒn somebody/something/  a copy of the way someone moves or talks, or of the style of a movie, book, etc that is done to make people laugh:

children.name: nhại, bắt chước
examples: ▪ A local television reporter dubbed him StyroCop - a take-off on the movie ‘RoboCop’ .

children.name: do a take-off of/on somebody
examples: ▪ Karen can do a hilarious take-off of Bette Davis.

children.name: emulate
children.definition: formal to copy sb else because you admire sth that they have done very much: làm theo, noi theo
examples: There is much in Cheng’s work that we can admire and emulate.
Developing countries often try to emulate experiences of developed countries, but this is not always a good idea.

children.name: model yourself on
children.definition: to copy sb’s behaviour and character as closely as you can because you want to be like them: bắt chước
examples: The junior Wimbledon champion said that she tried to model herself on Martina Navratilova.
Pender says his show models itself on the old-style talk shows.

children.name: to do the same things as other people in a group
follow the crowd
children.definition: /go (along) with the crowd  to do the same as the rest of a group of people because you have not really thought about what you want or because you do not want to disagree with what most people think: a dua, theo đám đông
examples: That experience taught me never to follow the crowd blindly.
It’s hard, as an investor, to resist the urge to go along with the crowd, but that isn’t where the money is.

children.name: jump on the bandwagon
children.definition: to do the same as a lot of other people are doing because you think there will be some advantage for you or because it is fashionable: chạy theo thị hiếu, chạy theo số đông, “xe chở dàn nhạc diễu hành”
examples: When they realized there was money to be made from games such as snooker, sportswear advertisers soon jumped on the bandwagon.
Opposition leaders have accused the government of jumping on the asylum seeker bandwagon.
